<summary>
• Lynne Neagle AM opened a session of the Children, Young People and Education Committee, welcoming Huw Irranca-Davies as a substitute for Dawn Bowden. The session focused on school improvement and raising standards, with Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Steve Davies, director of education, in attendance.
• Kirsty Williams discussed the ongoing involvement of the OECD in reviewing Welsh education, emphasizing its role in external verification and self-evaluation of the Welsh education system. The OECD's feedback has been integral to shaping the national mission for education in Wales.
• The Minister highlighted the use of powers under the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013, noting mixed effectiveness across local authorities in intervening in schools. Some local authorities actively use their powers, while others are less proactive.
• Kirsty Williams introduced the national evaluation and improvement resource aimed at enhancing self-evaluation in schools. This initiative, developed with input from the OECD and educational practitioners, is set to be implemented across the system.
• The discussion touched on the challenges of identifying schools needing support early enough, with a new multi-agency approach being piloted to address this issue. This approach includes collaboration between schools, local authorities, regional consortia, Estyn, and the Welsh Government.
• The Minister expressed concern over the consistency and effectiveness of regional consortia, which vary in their structure and operation. Despite initial intentions to abolish regional consortia, the need for scale in school improvement services has affirmed their continued relevance.
• Neath Port Talbot's notice to withdraw from the Education through Regional Working (ERW) consortium raised concerns about the potential impact on local school support. The Welsh Government is seeking assurances from Neath Port Talbot on how they will fulfill their educational responsibilities independently.
• The strategic delivery group led by Professor Dylan Jones aims to clarify roles and responsibilities within the middle tier of education governance. This group's work is crucial for the successful implementation of the new curriculum.
• Changes to performance measures in education have been made to prevent undesirable behaviors such as narrowing the curriculum and focusing excessively on borderline students. These interim measures are part of a broader strategy to evaluate educational outcomes more comprehensively.
• The Minister acknowledged the persistent challenge of closing the attainment gap for students eligible for free school meals despite significant investment through the pupil development grant. Efforts continue to address disparities in educational outcomes among disadvantaged groups.
</summary>

<summary>
• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, discussed the involvement of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in reviewing Welsh education. The OECD conducted a rapid review at the start of the Assembly term, influencing the national mission's publication. The OECD's ongoing relationship is seen as a tool for external verification of the Welsh education system, aiming to provide honest evaluations and aid in self-evaluation. The latest OECD report is expected to be published soon, with a government statement to follow.

• The discussion also covered the use of powers under the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013. Local authorities have extensive powers to intervene in schools, which have been used variably across Wales. Interventions include appointing additional governors and managing school finances directly. Successful interventions in Flintshire and Torfaen were highlighted, where schools moved out of special measures after the establishment of interim executive boards.

• The national evaluation and improvement resource was discussed as a significant tool for raising school standards. Initially developed with the OECD, this resource aims to improve self-evaluation practices within schools. It is currently in a testing phase and is expected to be rolled out across the system soon. The resource has been renamed from 'toolkit' to 'improvement resource' to better reflect its purpose beyond a simple checklist.

• Concerns about identifying schools needing urgent improvement were addressed. A new multi-agency approach is being piloted, involving local authorities, Welsh Government, and Estyn, to support schools causing significant concern. This approach aims for earlier intervention and sustainable improvement, rather than waiting for schools to require special measures. The pilot is being evaluated for its effectiveness in real-time school support.

• The role of regional consortia in school improvement was examined, particularly in light of local government structures and the potential withdrawal of Neath Port Talbot from the ERW consortium. The Minister emphasized the importance of regional consortia for providing scale in school improvement efforts, especially with the upcoming curriculum changes. Discussions are ongoing about the optimal organization of these consortia and their alignment with national education goals.
</summary>

* Lynne Neagle AM opened a session of the Children, Young People and Education Committee, noting apologies and substitutions among members. The committee was set to discuss school improvement and standards with Education Minister Kirsty Williams AM and Steve Davies, director of education.

* The discussion touched on the powers under the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013, particularly how local authorities use these powers to intervene in schools. Williams noted a mixed picture, with some authorities proactive and others less so, in using their powers effectively.

* Kirsty Williams discussed the development of a national evaluation and improvement resource aimed at raising school standards. This initiative focuses on robust self-evaluation practices across schools, supported by OECD and Estyn.

* The Minister stressed the importance of investment in professional learning, which constitutes a significant portion of the budget for school standards. This investment aims to support the ongoing professional development of teaching staff.

* Concerns were raised about the identification and support mechanisms for schools causing concern, particularly secondary schools. A new multi-agency approach involving local authorities, Welsh Government, and Estyn has been piloted to address these issues more effectively.

* The role of regional consortia in school improvement was scrutinized, with discussions on their consistency and effectiveness across regions. Williams defended the necessity of these consortia, especially without significant local government reform.

* The conversation also covered the changes in performance measures for schools, which have evolved to encourage a broader evaluation of school performance beyond just exam results. These changes aim to prevent narrow teaching practices and provide a more holistic view of educational outcomes.

* PISA results were discussed as a tool for measuring system-wide educational outcomes in Wales. While acknowledging the need for improvement, particularly in science and for disadvantaged students, Williams recognized PISA as one component of a broader assessment strategy.

* The persistent challenge of closing the attainment gap for pupils eligible for free school meals was addressed. Despite significant investment through the pupil development grant, disparities remain, highlighting the need for continued focus and adaptation of strategies.
</summary>

• The characters are interconnected through personal dilemmas, family dynamics, and the consequences of their choices, illustrating themes of love, betrayal, and redemption. Each character's journey is marked by challenges and the pursuit of personal integrity and happiness.
